results.question: Assume that a polyesterification is conducted in the absence of solvent or catalyst and that the monomers are present in stoichiometric ratios. Calculate the time (min) required to obtain a number-average degree of polymerization of 50 given that the initial dicarboxylic acid concentration is \( 3 \ \text{mol L}^{-1} \) and that the polymerization rate constant is \( 10^{-2} \ \text{L mol}^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \).
results.llm_output:
For a step‑growth polyesterification the number‑average degree of polymerization \(X_n\) is related to the conversion \(p\) by  

\[
X_n=\frac{1}{1-p}\; .
\]

Setting \(X_n=50\),

\[
\frac{1}{1-p}=50\;\Longrightarrow\;1-p=\frac{1}{50}=0.02\;\Longrightarrow\;p=0.98 .
\]

With stoichiometric amounts of the two monomers, the concentrations of the dicarboxylic acid \([A]\) and the diol \([B]\) are equal at any time: \([A]=[B]=C\).  
The rate law for the second‑order polyesterification is  

\[
-\frac{dC}{dt}=kC^{2},
\]

where \(k=10^{-2}\,\text{L mol}^{-1}\text{s}^{-1}\).

Integrating from the initial concentration \(C_0=3\;\text{mol L}^{-1}\) to the concentration \(C\) at time \(t\),

\[
\int_{C_0}^{C}\frac{dC}{C^{2}}=-k\int_{0}^{t}dt
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\Bigl[-\frac{1}{C}\Bigr]_{C_0}^{C}= -kt
\]

\[
\frac{1}{C}-\frac{1}{C_0}=kt .
\]

The concentration after conversion \(p\) is  

\[
C=C_0(1-p)=3\;(1-0.98)=3\times0.02=0.06\;\text{mol L}^{-1}.
\]

Thus  

\[
t=\frac{1/C-1/C_0}{k}
   =\frac{\displaystyle\frac{1}{0.06}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{3}}{10^{-2}}
   =\frac{16.6667-0.3333}{10^{-2}}
   =\frac{16.3334}{10^{-2}}
   \approx 1.63\times10^{3}\;\text{s}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.63\times10^{3}}\ \text{s}
\]

results.question: Give your best estimate for the weight fraction of plasticizer required to lower the \( T_{\text{g}} \) of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) to \( 30^\circ\text{C} \). Assume that the \( T_{\text{g}} \) of PVC is 356 K and that of the plasticizer is 188 K. No other information is available.
results.llm_output:
The Fox equation for the glass‑transition temperature of a binary polymer/plasticizer mixture is  

\[
\frac{1}{T_g}=w_{\text{PVC}}\frac{1}{T_{g,\text{PVC}}}+w_{\text{pl}}\frac{1}{T_{g,\text{pl}}},\qquad 
w_{\text{PVC}}+w_{\text{pl}}=1 .
\]

Let \(w_{\text{pl}}=x\).  Using  

\[
T_{g,\text{PVC}} = 356\ \text{K},\qquad 
T_{g,\text{pl}} = 188\ \text{K},\qquad 
T_g = 30^{\circ}\text{C}=303\ \text{K},
\]

\[
\frac{1}{303}= (1-x)\frac{1}{356}+x\frac{1}{188}.
\]

Solve for \(x\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{303} &= \frac{1}{356} -\frac{x}{356} +\frac{x}{188} \\
&= \frac{1}{356}+x\!\left(\frac{1}{188}-\frac{1}{356}\right)\\[4pt]
0.00330033 &= 0.00280899 + 0.00251016\,x\\[4pt]
0.00251016\,x &= 0.00049134\\[4pt]
x &\approx 0.196 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus the required plasticizer weight fraction is about \(0.196\), i.e. ≈ 19.6 wt %.

\[
\boxed{19.6}\ \text{wt\%}
\]

results.question: The 1% secant modulus of a polystyrene sample is 3 GPa. What is the nominal stress (MPa) of this sample at a nominal strain of 0.01?
results.llm_output:
The 1 % secant modulus \(E_{\text{sec}}\) is defined as  

\[
E_{\text{sec}}=\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon}
\]

at a nominal strain \(\varepsilon = 0.01\) (1 %).  
Given \(E_{\text{sec}} = 3\ \text{GPa}\),

\[
\sigma = E_{\text{sec}}\;\varepsilon = 3\ \text{GPa}\times 0.01 = 0.03\ \text{GPa}.
\]

Since \(1\ \text{GPa}=1000\ \text{MPa}\),

\[
\sigma = 0.03\ \text{GPa}\times 1000\ \frac{\text{MPa}}{\text{GPa}} = 30\ \text{MPa}.
\]

\[
\boxed{30}\ \text{MPa}
\]

results.question: Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and of \ce{H2O(l)} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the standard enthalpy change of combustion of \ce{H2} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The combustion of hydrogen at standard conditions is  

\[
\ce{H2(g) + \tfrac12 O2(g) -> H2O(l)}
\]

The standard enthalpy change is obtained from the standard enthalpies of formation:

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{comb}} = \sum \Delta H^\circ_{\text f,\,products}} - \sum \Delta H^\circ_{\text f,\,reactants}}
\]

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{comb}} = \bigl[\Delta H^\circ_{\text f}(\ce{H2O(l)})\bigr] -
\bigl[\Delta H^\circ_{\text f}(\ce{H2(g)}) + \tfrac12\Delta H^\circ_{\text f}(\ce{O2(g)})\bigr]
\]

Since \(\Delta H^\circ_{\text f}(\ce{H2(g)}) = \Delta H^\circ_{\text f}(\ce{O2(g)}) = 0\),

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{comb}} = -285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

results.question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{H2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
results.llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has the equilibrium constant (in terms of partial pressures)  

\[
K_{p}= \frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}\,P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}\,P_{\ce{H2O}}}=0.64 .
\]

Because the gases behave ideally, the partial pressures are proportional to the mole numbers, so  

\[
K_{p}= \frac{n_{\ce{CO2}}\,n_{\ce{H2}}}{n_{\ce{CO}}\,n_{\ce{H2O}}}.
\]

---

### 1.  Set up the ICE table  

Let \(\xi\) be the extent of the forward reaction (mol).  

\[
\begin{array}{c|cccc}
 & \ce{CO} & \ce{H2O} & \ce{CO2} & \ce{H2}\\ \hline
\text{Initial (mol)} & 40 & 40 & 20 & 20\\
\text{Change (mol)} & -\xi & -\xi & +\xi & +\xi\\
\text{Equilibrium (mol)} & 40-\xi & 40-\xi & 20+\xi & 20+\xi
\end{array}
\]

---

### 2.  Apply the equilibrium expression  

\[
0.64 = \frac{(20+\xi)(20+\xi)}{(40-\xi)(40-\xi)} .
\]

Taking the square root of both sides,

\[
\frac{20+\xi}{40-\xi}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8 .
\]

Solve for \(\xi\):

\[
20+\xi = 0.8(40-\xi) \\
20+\xi = 32 - 0.8\xi \\
1.8\xi = 12 \\
\xi = \frac{12}{1.8}=6.666\ldots\;\text{mol}.
\]

Thus, at equilibrium the amount of \(\ce{H2}\) present is  

\[
n_{\ce{H2,eq}} = 20 + \xi = 20 + 6.667 = 26.667\;\text{mol}.
\]

---

### 3.  Moles of \(\ce{H2}\) that leave  

The reactor initially contained 20 mol of \(\ce{H2}\).  
The excess \(\ce{H2}\) formed (and therefore available to leave) is  

\[
n_{\text{leaving}} = n_{\ce{H2,eq}} - n_{\ce{H2,initial}}
                    = 26.667\;\text{mol} - 20\;\text{mol}
                    = 6.667\;\text{mol}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{6.67\ \text{mol}}
\]

results.question: The mass of one gold atom is \pu{3.27E-22 g} and the density of gold is \pu{19.3 g cm^{-3}}. What is the molar volume of gold in \pu{cm^{3} mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The molar volume \(V_{\text{m}}\) is the volume occupied by one mole of gold:

\[
V_{\text{m}}=\frac{\text{mass of one mole}}{\text{density}}
\]

---

**1. Mass of one mole of Au**

Mass of a single Au atom: \(m_{\text{atom}} = 3.27\times10^{-22}\,\text{g}\)

Avogadro’s number: \(N_{\!A}=6.02214076\times10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\)

\[
m_{\text{mol}} = m_{\text{atom}}\;N_{\!A}
      = (3.27\times10^{-22}\,\text{g})\,(6.02214076\times10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1})
      \approx 1.969\times10^{2}\,\text{g}
\]

\[
m_{\text{mol}} \approx 1.969\times10^{2}\,\text{g} = 196.9\,\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

---

**2. Density of gold**

\[
\rho_{\text{Au}} = 19.3\;\text{g cm}^{-3}
\]

---

**3. Molar volume**

\[
V_{\text{m}} = \frac{m_{\text{mol}}}{\rho_{\text{Au}}}
            = \frac{196.9\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{19.3\;\text{g cm}^{-3}}
            \approx 10.2\;\text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{10.2}\ \text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}
\]

What is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6NaF + 6HCl -> H2SiF6 + 6NaCl + 2H2O} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?"""

Model's reasoning: """The target reaction can be obtained by combining the given reactions as follows  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{(i) } &\ce{NaOH + HCl -> NaCl + H2O}\qquad \Delta H_1 = -56.7\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\[2mm]
\text{(ii) } &\ce{SiO2 + 6HF -> H2SiF6 + 2H2O}\qquad \Delta H_2 = -100.3\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\[2mm]
\text{(iii) } &\ce{NaOH + HF -> H2O + NaF}\qquad \Delta H_3 = -61.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

Reverse (iii) and multiply by 6:

\[
6\ce{NaF} + 6\ce{H2O} \rightarrow 6\ce{NaOH} + 6\ce{HF}\qquad \Delta H = +6(61.5)=+369.0\ \text{kJ}
\]

Multiply (i) by 6:

\[
6\ce{NaOH} + 6\ce{HCl} \rightarrow 6\ce{NaCl} + 6\ce{H2O}\qquad \Delta H = 6(-56.7)=-340.2\ \text{kJ}
\]

Add the three equations:

\begin{aligned}

\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\ce{SiO2 + 6NaF + 6HCl -> H2SiF6 + 6NaCl + 2H2O}
\]

The overall enthalpy change is the sum of the individual ΔH values:

\[
\Delta H^\circ = (+369.0) + (-340.2) + (-100.3) = -71.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-71.5}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]"""

Model's final answer: -71.5

results.question: The molar volume of gold is \pu{10.2 cm^{3} mol^{-1}}. The gold atoms occupy 74 % of the volume of the cubic unit cell. What is the radius of the gold atom in \pu{\A}?
results.llm_output:
The gold crystal is face‑centered cubic (FCC).  
For an FCC lattice  

\[
a = 2\sqrt{2}\,r ,\qquad V_{\text{cell}} = a^{3}=16\sqrt{2}\,r^{3}
\]

and the four atoms per cell occupy  

\[
V_{\text{atoms}} = 4\;\frac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}= \frac{16}{3}\pi r^{3}
\]

The packing factor is  

\[
\frac{V_{\text{atoms}}}{V_{\text{cell}}}= \frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}} \approx 0.74,
\]

as given in the problem.

The molar volume of gold is  

\[
V_m = 10.2\;\text{cm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

so the volume per atom is  

\[
V_{\text{atom}} = \frac{V_m}{N_A}
      = \frac{10.2\;\text{cm}^{3}}{6.022\times10^{23}}
      = 1.693\times10^{-23}\;\text{cm}^{3}
\]

Converting to cubic ångströms \(\bigl(1\;\text{cm}^{3}=10^{24}\;\text{\AA}^{3}\bigr)\),

\[
V_{\text{atom}} = 1.693\times10^{-23}\times10^{24}
                = 1.693\times10^{1}\;\text{\AA}^{3}
                = 16.93\;\text{\AA}^{3}.
\]

Four atoms belong to one unit cell, thus  

\[
V_{\text{cell}} = 4\,V_{\text{atom}} = 4 \times 16.93 = 67.72\;\text{\AA}^{3}.
\]

Hence the lattice parameter  

\[
a = V_{\text{cell}}^{1/3}= (67.72)^{1/3}\;\text{\AA}
   \approx 4.08\;\text{\AA}.
\]

Finally, the atomic radius follows from \(a = 2\sqrt{2}\,r\):

\[
r = \frac{a}{2\sqrt{2}}
   = \frac{4.08}{2\sqrt{2}}
   \approx \frac{4.08}{2.828}
   \approx 1.44\;\text{\AA}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.44\ \text{\AA}}
\]

Question: """\pu{286000 tonnes} of polylactic acid (PLA) are manufactured each year. What is the mass of NaOH, in tonnes, needed to completely degrade all the PLA manufactured in one year to sodium lactate, assume the PLA is pure and ignoring the contribution from any end groups?"""

Model's reasoning: """The hydrolysis of a PLA repeat unit with sodium hydroxide is  

\[
\underbrace{\mathrm{C_3H_4O_2}}_{\text{PLA repeat}}+ \mathrm{NaOH}\;\longrightarrow\; \underbrace{\mathrm{C_3H_5O_3Na}}_{\text{sodium lactate}}
\]

Thus **1 mol NaOH** is required for **1 mol** of PLA repeat units.

---

### 1.  Molar mass of the PLA repeat unit  

\[
\begin{aligned}
M_{\text{repeat}} &= 3M_{\mathrm C}+4M_{\mathrm H}+2M_{\mathrm O}\\
&=3(12.011)+4(1.008)+2(15.999)\\
&\approx 72.06\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

### 2.  Moles of PLA produced per year  

\[
\begin{aligned}
m_{\text{PLA}} &= 286\,000\ \text{tonne}=2.86\times10^{11}\ \text{g}\\[4pt]
n_{\text{PLA}} &= \frac{m_{\text{PLA}}}{M_{\text{repeat}}}
               =\frac{2.86\times10^{11}\ \text{g}}{72.06\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}\\
               &\approx 3.97\times10^{9}\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

### 3.  Moles (and mass) of NaOH required  

\[
n_{\text{NaOH}} = n_{\text{PLA}} \approx 3.97\times10^{9}\ \text{mol}
\]

\[

m_{\text{NaOH}} &= n_{\text{NaOH}}\;M_{\text{NaOH}}\\

results.question: There are \pu{7.1E6} virus particles per \pu{cm^{3}} in the test solution. Each virus particle has approximately 20 spike proteins on its surface. What is the concentration of spike proteins, [SP], in the test sample in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
results.llm_output:
The number of virus particles per cubic decimetre is  

\[
7.1\times10^{6}\;\text{cm}^{-3}\times\frac{10^{3}\;\text{cm}^{3}}{1\;\text{dm}^{3}}
=7.1\times10^{9}\;\text{particles dm}^{-3}.
\]

Each particle carries 20 spike proteins, so the spike‑protein number density is  

\[
7.1\times10^{9}\times20 = 1.42\times10^{11}\;\text{spike proteins dm}^{-3}.
\]

Converting to moles using Avogadro’s number \(N_{\mathrm A}=6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}\),

\[
[\text{SP}] = \frac{1.42\times10^{11}}{6.022\times10^{23}}
= 2.36\times10^{-13}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.36E-13}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

results.question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{H2O} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
results.llm_output:
The equilibrium composition can be obtained from the extent of reaction \(x\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40 - x \\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40 - x \\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20 + x \\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20 + x
\end{aligned}
\]

For an ideal‑gas mixture at constant total pressure,  

\[
K_p=\frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{n_{\ce{CO2}}\,n_{\ce{H2}}}{n_{\ce{CO}}\,n_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{(20+x)^2}{(40-x)^2}=0.64 .
\]

Taking the square root,

\[
\frac{20+x}{40-x}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8,
\]

\[
20+x = 0.8(40-x)=32-0.8x \;\Longrightarrow\; 1.8x = 12,
\]

\[
x = \frac{12}{1.8}= \frac{20}{3}\;\text{mol}.
\]

Hence the equilibrium amount of water remaining (and thus leaving the reactor) is

\[
n_{\ce{H2O,eq}} = 40 - x = 40 - \frac{20}{3}= \frac{100}{3}\;\text{mol}.
\]

\[
\boxed{\frac{100}{3}\ \text{mol}}
\]

results.question: The enthalpy change of vaporization of methane is \pu{8.2 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy change of vaporization of oxygen is \pu{6.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. The enthalpy change of combustion of methane, \ce{CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)}, is \pu{-890.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy change of reaction, in \pu{kJ}, when one mole of liquid methane reacts with liquid oxygen to form gaseous carbon dioxide and gaseous water?
results.llm_output:
The combustion of gaseous methane and oxygen releases  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{comb}}^{\;(\text{g})}= -890.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

To start from the liquid reactants we must vaporise them:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{CH}_4(l) &\rightarrow \text{CH}_4(g) &&\Delta H = +8.2\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\[2pt]
2\,\text{O}_2(l) &\rightarrow 2\,\text{O}_2(g) &&\Delta H = 2\times(+6.8)=+13.6\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus the total enthalpy required to bring the reactants to the gaseous state is  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{vap}} = 8.2 + 13.6 = +21.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Adding this to the combustion enthalpy gives the enthalpy change for the reaction starting from liquid methane and liquid oxygen:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{reaction}} = \Delta H_{\text{comb}}^{\;(\text{g})} + \Delta H_{\text{vap}}
= -890.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1} + 21.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
= -869.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-869\ \text{kJ}}
\]

\]

\[
n_{\ce{Cl^{-}}}=8.20\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

The total solution volume is 250 cm³, i.e. ten times larger, so the whole bag contains  

\[
n_{\text{Cl}^{-},\text{bag}} = 10 \times 8.20\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}

\]

All chloride originates from NaCl, whose molar mass is \(M_{\ce{NaCl}} = 58.44\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\).

results.question: A catalyst for the hydrogenation of levulinic acid is the octahedral complex of formula \ce{[RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3]}. This complex is named dihydridocarbonyltris(triphenylphosphine)ruthenium(Z), where Z is the oxidation state of ruthenium. What is the integer Z?
results.llm_output:
The oxidation state \(Z\) of ruthenium is found by balancing the charges of the ligands:

- Each hydride \( \ce{H^{-}} \) contributes \(-1\) (two of them give \(-2\)).
- Carbonyl \( \ce{CO} \) and triphenylphosphine \( \ce{PPh_{3}} \) are neutral ligands (charge \(0\)).

For a neutral complex,
\[
Z + (-2) + 0 + 0 = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; Z = +2.
\]

\[
\boxed{2}
\]

results.question: What is the bond enthalpy of the \ce{O=O} bond in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}, given that the bond enthalpy of the \ce{H-H} bond is \pu{432 kJ mol^{-1}}, the average bond enthalpy of \ce{O-H} is \pu{460 kJ mol^{-1}}, and the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{H2 + 0.5 O2 -> H2O} is \pu{-241 kJ} per mole of hydrogen gas?
results.llm_output:
The enthalpy change for a reaction can be expressed in terms of bond enthalpies as  

\[
\Delta H = \sum \text{(bond enthalpies of bonds broken)}-
           \sum \text{(bond enthalpies of bonds formed)} .
\]

For the reaction  

\[
\ce{H2 + \tfrac12 O2 -> H2O}
\]

the bonds involved are  

* **Broken:** one \(\ce{H–H}\) bond \((D_{\ce{H–H}} = 432\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})\) and half of an \(\ce{O=O}\) bond \(\bigl(\tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\bigr)\).  
* **Formed:** two \(\ce{O–H}\) bonds in water, each with an average bond enthalpy of \(460\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\).

Hence  

\[
\Delta H = \bigl[432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\bigr] - \bigl[2 \times 460\bigr].
\]

The experimental enthalpy change for the reaction is \(\Delta H = -241\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\) (per mole of \(\ce{H2}\)).  
Insert this value and solve for \(D_{\ce{O=O}}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
-241 &= \bigl[432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\bigr] - 920,\\[4pt]
-241 &= -488 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}},\\[4pt]
\tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} &= 247,\\[4pt]
D_{\ce{O=O}} &= 2 \times 247 = 494\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{494}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

results.question: What is the oxidation number of carbon in the reactants of Sabatier reaction?
results.llm_output:
The Sabatier reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O}
\]

In the reactant \(\mathrm{CO_2}\), oxygen has an oxidation number of \(-2\).  
Let the oxidation number of carbon be \(x\). Then  

\[
x + 2(-2) = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; x = +4 .
\]

Thus, the oxidation number of carbon in the reactants is  

\[
\boxed{+4}
\]

results.question: The density of liquid hydrogen is \pu{0.071 g cm^{-3}}. Assume the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{H2 + 0.5 O2 -> H2O} is \pu{-241 kJ} per mole of hydrogen gas. What is the energy released, in \pu{kJ}, when the gas formed from \pu{1 dm^{3}} of liquid hydrogen is combusted?
results.llm_output:
The volume of liquid hydrogen is  

\[
V = 1\ \text{dm}^{3}=1000\ \text{cm}^{3}
\]

With a density \(\rho = 0.071\ \text{g cm}^{-3}\),

\[
m = \rho V = 0.071\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^{3}}\times 1000\ \text{cm}^{3}=71\ \text{g}
\]

Moles of \(\ce{H2}\) (molar mass \(M_{\ce{H2}} = 2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}\)):

\[
n = \frac{m}{M_{\ce{H2}}}= \frac{71\ \text{g}}{2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}} \approx 35.24\ \text{mol}
\]

The enthalpy change for the combustion of one mole of \(\ce{H2}\) is  

\[
\Delta H = -241\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Hence the total energy released is

\[
E = n\,\Delta H = 35.24\ \text{mol}\times (-241\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})
      \approx -8.5\times10^{3}\ \text{kJ}
\]

(The negative sign indicates release of energy.)

\[
\boxed{8.5\times10^{3}\ \text{kJ}}
\]

results.question: If ten tonnes of Ambrox (\ce{C16H28O}) are produced every year, what is the number of moles produced per year?
results.llm_output:
The number of moles \(n\) is obtained from the mass \(m\) and the molar mass \(M\):

\[
n=\frac{m}{M}
\]

**Mass of Ambrox per year**

\[
10\ \text{tonnes}=10\times10^{3}\ \text{kg}=10\times10^{6}\ \text{g}=1.0\times10^{7}\ \text{g}
\]

**Molar mass of \(\ce{C_{16}H_{28}O}\)**  

\[
M = 16(12.01\ \text{g mol}^{-1}) + 28(1.008\ \text{g mol}^{-1}) + 1(16.00\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
   = 236.38\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

**Moles produced per year**

\[
n = \frac{1.0\times10^{7}\ \text{g}}{236.38\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
   \approx 4.23\times10^{4}\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
\boxed{4.23\times10^{4}\ \text{mol}}
\]

results.question: Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}}, of \ce{CO2(g)} is \pu{-393.5 kJ mol^{-1}} and it is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{H2O(l)}. What is the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{CH4(g) + 2H2O(l) -> CO2(g) + 4H2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The enthalpy change for a reaction is obtained from the standard enthalpies of formation:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^{\circ}= \sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^{\circ}(\text{products})-\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^{\circ}(\text{reactants})
\]

For  

\[
\ce{CH4(g) + 2 H2O(l) -> CO2(g) + 4 H2(g)}
\]

the standard formation enthalpies are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_f^{\circ}[\ce{CH4(g)}] &= -74.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
\Delta H_f^{\circ}[\ce{CO2(g)}] &= -393.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
\Delta H_f^{\circ}[\ce{H2O(l)}] &= -285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
\Delta H_f^{\circ}[\ce{H2(g)}] &= 0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

Calculate the sums:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^{\circ}(\text{products}) &= (-393.5) + 4(0) = -393.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\[4pt]
\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^{\circ}(\text{reactants}) &= (-74.8) + 2(-285.8) = -74.8 - 571.6 = -646.4\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}^{\circ}= -393.5 - (-646.4)= 252.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{252.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

results.question: The average bond enthalpy of \ce{C-C} is \pu{347 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-H} is \pu{413 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{O=O} is \pu{498 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-O} is \pu{358 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C=O} is \pu{805 kJ mol^{-1}} and \ce{O-H} is \pu{464 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The combustion of any octane isomer is  

\[
\ce{C8H18 + \tfrac{25}{2} O2 -> 8 CO2 + 9 H2O}
\]

Using average bond enthalpies, the reaction enthalpy is  

\[
\Delta H \approx \sum\text{(bonds broken)}-\sum\text{(bonds formed)}
\]

**Bonds broken (reactants)**  

- C–C: \(7 \times 347 = 2429\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)  
- C–H: \(18 \times 413 = 7434\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)  
- O=O: \(\frac{25}{2}\times 498 = 12.5 \times 498 = 6225\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)

\[
\sum\text{broken}=2429+7434+6225=16088\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

**Bonds formed (products)**  

- C=O (in CO₂): \(8\times2 \times 805 = 16 \times 805 = 12880\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)  
- O–H (in H₂O): \(9\times2 \times 464 = 18 \times 464 = 8352\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)

\[
\sum\text{formed}=12880+8352=21232\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

**Enthalpy of combustion**

\[
\Delta H = 16088 - 21232 = -5144\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-5144\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

results.question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
results.llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has the equilibrium constant  

\[
K_{p}= \frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}=0.64 .
\]

Let \(\xi\) be the extent of the forward reaction (mol).  
The initial amounts are  

\[
n_{\ce{CO}}^{0}=40,\; n_{\ce{H2O}}^{0}=40,\; n_{\ce{CO2}}^{0}=20,\; n_{\ce{H2}}^{0}=20 .
\]

At equilibrium  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20+\xi,\\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20+\xi .
\end{aligned}
\]

Because one mole of reactants produces one mole of products, the total number of moles stays constant:

\[
n_{\text{tot}} = 40+40+20+20 = 120\;\text{mol}.
\]

Hence the mole fractions are \(y_i=n_i/120\). Substituting into the expression for \(K_p\),

\[
K_{p}= \frac{y_{\ce{CO2}}\,y_{\ce{H2}}}{y_{\ce{CO}}\,y_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{(20+\xi)^2}{(40-\xi)^2}=0.64 .
\]

Taking the square root,

\[
\frac{20+\xi}{40-\xi}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8 .
\]

Solving for \(\xi\),

\[
20+\xi = 0.8(40-\xi) \\
20+\xi = 32-0.8\xi \\
1.8\xi = 12 \\
\xi = \frac{12}{1.8}= \frac{20}{3}\;\text{mol}\approx 6.7\;\text{mol}.
\]

\(\xi\) is the amount of \(\ce{CO}\) that reacts (leaves the reactor).  

\[
\boxed{\frac{20}{3}\ \text{mol}}
\]

At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO} leaving the reactor after equilibration?"""

Model's reasoning: """The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has the equilibrium constant  

\[
K_{p}= \frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}=0.64 .
\]

Let \(\xi\) be the extent of the forward reaction (mol).  
The initial amounts are  

\[
n_{\ce{CO}}^{0}=40,\; n_{\ce{H2O}}^{0}=40,\; n_{\ce{CO2}}^{0}=20,\; n_{\ce{H2}}^{0}=20 .
\]

At equilibrium  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20+\xi,\\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20+\xi .
\end{aligned}
\]

Because one mole of reactants produces one mole of products, the total number of moles stays constant:

\[
n_{\text{tot}} = 40+40+20+20 = 120\;\text{mol}.
\]

Hence the mole fractions are \(y_i=n_i/120\). Substituting into the expression for \(K_p\),

\[
K_{p}= \frac{y_{\ce{CO2}}\,y_{\ce{H2}}}{y_{\ce{CO}}\,y_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{(20+\xi)^2}{(40-\xi)^2}=0.64 .
\]

Taking the square root,

\[
\frac{20+\xi}{40-\xi}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8 .
\]

Solving for \(\xi\),

\[
20+\xi = 0.8(40-\xi) \\
20+\xi = 32-0.8\xi \\
1.8\xi = 12 \\
\xi = \frac{12}{1.8}= \frac{20}{3}\;\text{mol}\approx 6.7\;\text{mol}.
\]

\(\xi\) is the amount of \(\ce{CO}\) that reacts (leaves the reactor).  

\[
\boxed{\frac{20}{3}\ \text{mol}}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 6.666667\ \text{mol}

Correct answer: 33.3

Judgement:

results.question: An impure sample of calcium carbide of mass \pu{0.752 g} was added to \pu{50 cm^{3}} of water. After all the calcium carbide had reacted, \pu{20 cm^{3}} of the reaction mixture was removed and titrated against \pu{0.250 mol dm^{-3}} hydrochloric acid. \pu{34.60 cm^{3}} of hydrochloric acid was required to neutralize the sample. It can be assumed that none of the impurities reacted. What is the percentage purity of the calcium carbide?
results.llm_output:
The reaction of calcium carbide with water is  

\[
\ce{CaC2 + 2 H2O -> C2H2 + Ca(OH)2}
\]

The calcium hydroxide formed is titrated with hydrochloric acid:

\[
\ce{Ca(OH)2 + 2 HCl -> CaCl2 + 2 H2O}
\]

---

**1. Moles of HCl used in the titration**

\[
V_{\ce{HCl}} = 34.60\ \text{cm}^{3}=0.03460\ \text{L}
\]
\[
M_{\ce{HCl}} = 0.250\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

\[
n_{\ce{HCl}} = M V = 0.250 \times 0.03460 = 8.65\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

**2. Moles of \(\ce{Ca(OH)2}\) in the 20 cm³ aliquot**

\[
\ce{Ca(OH)2 + 2 HCl}
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
n_{\ce{Ca(OH)2}} = \frac{n_{\ce{HCl}}}{2}
               = \frac{8.65\times10^{-3}}{2}
               = 4.325\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

**3. Moles of \(\ce{Ca(OH)2}\) (and thus \(\ce{CaC2}\)) in the whole 50 cm³ mixture**

\[
\frac{50\ \text{cm}^{3}}{20\ \text{cm}^{3}} = 2.5
\]

\[
n_{\ce{CaC2}} = 4.325\times10^{-3}\times 2.5
               = 1.0813\times10^{-2}\ \text{mol}
\]

**4. Mass of pure \(\ce{CaC2}\) present**

\[
M_{\ce{CaC2}} = 40.078 + 2(12.011) = 64.10\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
m_{\ce{CaC2}} = n_{\ce{CaC2}} \times M_{\ce{CaC2}}
               = 1.0813\times10^{-2}\times 64.10
               = 0.693\ \text{g}
\]

**5. Percentage purity**

\[
\%\,\text{purity} = \frac{0.693\ \text{g}}{0.752\ \text{g}}\times 100
                 = 92.1\%
\]

\[
\boxed{92.1\%}
\]

results.question: EDTA reacts with copper ions according to the equation \ce{Cu^{2+} + EDTA4_{(aq)} -> [CuEDTA]^{2-}_{(aq)}}. The end-point of the titration was determined using an indicator called murexide, and it was found that \pu{0.1 g} of X required \pu{21.70 cm^{3}} of \pu{0.02 mol dm^{-3}} EDTA solution for complete reaction. What is the percent by mass of copper in compound X?
results.llm_output:
The titration reaction is  

\[
\ce{Cu^{2+} + EDTA^{4-} -> [CuEDTA]^{2-}}
\]

so the moles of \(\ce{Cu^{2+}}\) in the sample equal the moles of EDTA used.

**Moles of EDTA used**

\[
n_{\text{EDTA}} = C \times V = (0.02\ \text{mol dm}^{-3})\times(21.70\ \text{cm}^{3}\times10^{-3}\ \text{dm}^{3}\,\text{cm}^{-3})
               = 0.02 \times 0.02170 = 4.34\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

Thus  

\[
n_{\text{Cu}} = 4.34\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

**Mass of copper in the sample**

\[
m_{\text{Cu}} = n_{\text{Cu}}\times M_{\text{Cu}}
               = 4.34\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}\times 63.55\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
               = 2.758\times10^{-2}\ \text{g}
\]

**Percent by mass of copper in X**

\[
\%\,\text{Cu} = \frac{m_{\text{Cu}}}{m_{\text{X}}}\times 100
              = \frac{2.758\times10^{-2}\ \text{g}}{0.100\ \text{g}}\times 100
              = 27.6\%
\]

\[
\boxed{27.6\%}
\]

Question: """The enthalpy of combustion of ethanol is \pu{-1276 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane is \pu{-5144 kJ mol^{-1}}. Assume that \pu{1 L} of E5 fuel contains \pu{50 mL} of ethanol and \pu{950 mL} of octane isomers. The density of pure ethanol is \pu{0.789 g cm^{-3}} and the density of pure octane isomers is \pu{0.703 g cm^{-3}}. What is the energy, in \pu{kJ}, released when \pu{1 L} of the E5 fuel is burnt?"""

Model's reasoning: """The energy released is the sum of the contributions from ethanol and the octane isomers.

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Mass of ethanol} &= 0.789\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^3}\times 50\;\text{cm}^3 = 39.45\;\text{g} \\
\text{Moles of ethanol} &= \frac{39.45\;\text{g}}{46.07\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.856\;\text{mol} \\[4pt]
\text{Mass of octane isomers} &= 0.703\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^3}\times 950\;\text{cm}^3 = 667.85\;\text{g} \\
\text{Moles of octane isomers} &= \frac{667.85\;\text{g}}{114.23\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 5.85\;\text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Energy from ethanol:

\[
E_{\text{eth}} = 0.856\;\text{mol}\times 1276\;\frac{\text{kJ}}{\text{mol}} = 1.09\times10^{3}\;\text{kJ}
\]

Energy from octane isomers:

\[
E_{\text{oct}} = 5.85\;\text{mol}\times 5144\;\frac{\text{kJ}}{\text{mol}} = 3.01\times10^{4}\;\text{kJ}
\]

Total energy released per litre of E5 fuel:

\[
E_{\text{total}} = E_{\text{eth}} + E_{\text{oct}} = 1.09\times10^{3}\;\text{kJ} + 3.01\times10^{4}\;\text{kJ}
               = 3.12\times10^{4}\;\text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{3.12\times10^{4}\ \text{kJ}}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 3.120000E+04\ \text{kJ}

Correct answer: 31170.0

results.question: A standard small bag typically contains \pu{22 g} of a snack. When a \pu{2.0 g} sample of the snack is completely burned, it results in a temperature rise of \pu{20.9 deg C} in \pu{500 g} of water within the calorimeter. The specific heat capacity of water is \pu{4.18 J K^{-1} g^{-1}}, and the conversion factor from kilojoules (kJ) to dietary calories is 0.239. What is the dietary calories content in a standard small bag of the snack?
results.llm_output:
The heat released by the combustion of the sample is transferred to the water in the calorimeter.

\[
q = m_{\text{water}}\,c_{\text{water}}\,\Delta T
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
q &= (500\;\text{g})\;(4.18\;\text{J g}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})\;(20.9\;\text{K})  \\
  &= 500 \times 4.18 \times 20.9\;\text{J} \\
  &= 4.37\times 10^{4}\;\text{J}= 43.7\;\text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

This heat corresponds to the combustion of the \(2.0\;\text{g}\) sample, so the energy per gram of snack is

\[
\frac{43.7\;\text{kJ}}{2.0\;\text{g}} = 21.9\;\text{kJ g}^{-1}.
\]

For a full small bag (\(22\;\text{g}\)) the total energy is

\[
E_{\text{bag}} = 21.9\;\text{kJ g}^{-1}\times 22\;\text{g}=4.81\times10^{2}\;\text{kJ}.
\]

Convert kilojoules to dietary calories (kilocalories) using the given factor \(1\;\text{kJ}=0.239\;\text{kcal}\):

\[
\text{Calories}_{\text{bag}} = 4.81\times10^{2}\;\text{kJ}\times 0.239\;\frac{\text{kcal}}{\text{kJ}}
= 1.15\times10^{2}\;\text{kcal}.
\]

\[
\boxed{115\ \text{kcal}}
\]

results.question: What is the average molar mass of polymer chains in a polylactic acid (PLA) sample, measured in grams per mole, based on the dissolution of \pu{0.1619 g} of PLA in \pu{25 cm^{3}} of benzyl alcohol and titration with a \pu{0.04 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{KOH} solution, yielding a titre of \pu{6.81 cm^{3}}?
results.llm_output:
The titration determines the number of terminal –COOH groups, i.e. the number of polymer chains present in the sample.

\[
\begin{aligned}
V_{\text{KOH}} &= 6.81\ \text{cm}^{3}=6.81\times10^{-3}\ \text{L}=0.00681\ \text{dm}^{3} \\
c_{\text{KOH}} &= 0.04\ \text{mol dm}^{-3} \\
n_{\text{KOH}} &= c_{\text{KOH}}\;V_{\text{KOH}}
               =0.04\ \frac{\text{mol}}{\text{dm}^{3}}\times0.00681\ \text{dm}^{3} \\
               &=2.724\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Each mole of KOH neutralises one mole of –COOH, therefore the amount of polymer chains in the sample is  

\[
n_{\text{chains}} = 2.724\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}.
\]

The mass of PLA used is  

\[
m = 0.1619\ \text{g}.
\]

Hence the average molar mass of a polymer chain is  

\[
M_{\text{avg}} = \frac{m}{n_{\text{chains}}}
               = \frac{0.1619\ \text{g}}{2.724\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}}
               \approx 5.95\times10^{2}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{5.95\times10^{2}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
\]

Question: """The reaction for the explosion of TNT is \ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}. What the mass (in \pu{g}) of TNT that will explode to produce \pu{1.0 dm^{3}} of gas at room temperature and pressure, assuming that the molar volume of any gas is \pu{24 dm^{3}} at RTP?"""

Model's reasoning: """The balanced decomposition of TNT is  

\[
\ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}
\]

Only the gaseous products contribute to the gas volume.  
At room temperature and pressure (RTP) the gases are  

\[
\ce{CO},\ \ce{CO2},\ \ce{H2},\ \ce{N2},\ \ce{H2O}
\]

Hence the number of moles of gas formed per mole of TNT is  

\[
n_{\text{gas}} = 3(\ce{CO}) + 1(\ce{CO2}) + 1.5(\ce{H2}) + 1.5(\ce{N2}) + 1(\ce{H2O})
               = 8.0\ \text{mol}
\]

At RTP the molar volume of any gas is  

\[
V_{\text{m}} = 24\ \text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

Thus one mole of TNT would produce  

\[
V_{\text{gas}} = n_{\text{gas}}\;V_{\text{m}} = 8.0 \times 24 = 192\ \text{dm}^{3}
\]

We need only \(V = 1.0\ \text{dm}^{3}\) of gas, so the required amount of TNT is  

\[
n_{\text{TNT}} = \frac{V}{V_{\text{gas}}}
               = \frac{1.0}{192}
               = 5.21\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

The molar mass of TNT (\(\ce{C7H5N3O6}\)) is  

\[
M_{\text{TNT}} = 7(12.01) + 5(1.008) + 3(14.01) + 6(16.00)
               \approx 227\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
m = n_{\text{TNT}}\,M_{\text{TNT}}
   = 5.21\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\times 227\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
   \approx 1.2\ \text{g}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.2\ \text{g}}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 1.2\ \text{g}

results.question: What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphoric acid?
results.llm_output:
The oxidation numbers in a neutral compound must sum to zero.

\[
\text{H}_3\text{PO}_4:\qquad 3(\text{oxidation state of H})+(\text{oxidation state of P})+4(\text{oxidation state of O})=0
\]

- Hydrogen in most compounds has an oxidation state of \(+1\).
- Oxygen in most compounds has an oxidation state of \(-2\).

Let the oxidation state of phosphorus be \(x\). Then

\[
3(+1)+x+4(-2)=0 \\
3 + x - 8 = 0 \\
x = +5
\]

\[
\boxed{+5}
\]

results.question: What is the oxidation number of carbon in the products of Sabatier reaction?
results.llm_output:
The Sabatier reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O}
\]

In the product methane (\(\mathrm{CH_4}\)), hydrogen has an oxidation state of \(+1\).  
Since there are four hydrogens, the total oxidation contribution from hydrogen is  

\[
4 \times (+1)=+4.
\]

The molecule is neutral, so the oxidation state of carbon must balance this charge:

\[
\text{Oxidation state of C} + (+4) = 0 \;\Longrightarrow\; \text{Oxidation state of C}= -4.
\]

Thus, the oxidation number of carbon in the product of the Sabatier reaction is  

\[
\boxed{-4}
\]

Question: """Assuming a bubble appearing during fermentation in cheese with diameter \pu{1.5 cm} at \pu{21 deg C} is pure \ce{CO2} at atmospheric pressure, p = \pu{101325 Pa}, what is the mass, in grams, of lactic acid which was fermented by the bacteria to produce this bubble?"""

Model's reasoning: """The bubble is a sphere of diameter \(d = \pu{1.5 cm}\).

---

### 1. Volume of the bubble  

\[
r = \frac{d}{2}=0.75\ \text{cm}=0.0075\ \text{m}
\]

\[
V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}
   = \frac{4}{3}\pi (0.0075\ \text{m})^{3}
   = 1.77\times10^{-6}\ \text{m}^{3}
   = 1.77\times10^{-3}\ \text{L}
\]

---

### 2. Amount of \(\ce{CO2}\) in the bubble  

Use the ideal‑gas law \(pV = nRT\).

\[
p = \pu{101325 Pa},\qquad
T = 21^{\circ}\text{C}=294\ \text{K},\qquad
R = 8.314\ \frac{\text{J}}{\text{mol·K}}
\]

\[
n_{\ce{CO2}} = \frac{pV}{RT}
   = \frac{(1.01325\times10^{5}\ \text{Pa})(1.77\times10^{-6}\ \text{m}^{3})}
          {(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(294\ \text{K})}
   = 7.3\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol}
\]

---

### 3. Relation to lactic acid formation  

In hetero‑fermentative lactic‑acid bacteria:

\[
\ce{C6H12O6 -> CH3CH(OH)COOH + CO2 + H2O}
\]

One mole of \(\ce{CO2}\) is produced per mole of lactic acid formed, so

\[
n_{\text{lactic acid}} = n_{\ce{CO2}} = 7.3\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol}
\]

---

### 4. Mass of lactic acid  

Molar mass of lactic acid \(\ce{C3H6O3}\):

\[
M = 3(12.011) + 6(1.008) + 3(15.999) = 90.08\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
m = nM = (7.3\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol})(90.08\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
    = 6.6\times10^{-3}\ \text{g}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{6.6\times10^{-3}\ \text{g}}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 0.0066\ \text{g}

Correct answer: 0.0198

results.question: What is the oxidation number of hydrogen in the products of Sabatier reaction?
results.llm_output:
In the Sabatier reaction  

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O},
\]

the products are methane (\(\mathrm{CH_4}\)) and water (\(\mathrm{H_2O}\)).  

- In \(\mathrmCH_4}\), the oxidation state of carbon is \(-4\). Since the molecule is neutral, the four hydrogens must each have an oxidation state of \(+1\).  
- In \(\mathrm{H_2O}\), oxygen is \(-2\); therefore each hydrogen again has an oxidation state of \(+1\).

Thus, the oxidation number of hydrogen in **both** products is  

\[
\boxed{+1}
\]

results.question: The density of pure water is \pu{1 g cm^{-3}}, the melting point of pure water is \pu{273 K} and the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water is \pu{6.01 kJ mol^{-1}}. The depression in freezing point can be calculated by $ rac{nRT_\mathrm{melt}^2}{\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}}$, where $n$ is the amount of substance (in \pu{mol}) of ions, $R$ is the gas constant, $T_\mathrm{melt}$ is the melting point of pure water, and $\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}$ is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water. What is the freezing point of a \pu{3 mol dm^{-3}} solution of sodium chloride in \pu{K}?
results.llm_output:
The freezing‑point depression for an aqueous electrolyte is  

\[
\Delta T_{\mathrm f}=i\,K_{\mathrm f}\,m ,
\]

where  

* \(i\) = van ’t Hoff factor (for NaCl, \(i=2\)),  
* \(K_{\mathrm f}= \dfrac{R\,T_{\text{melt}}^{2}\,M_{\mathrm w}}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}\) is the cryoscopic constant of water,  
* \(m\) = molality of the solute (mol kg\(^{-1}\)), and  
* \(M_{\mathrm w}=18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}=0.018015\;\text{kg mol}^{-1}\).

Using the given data  

\[
K_{\mathrm f}= \frac{(8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(273\;\text{K})^{2}(0.018015\;\text{kg mol}^{-1})}
{6.01\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}}
=1.86\;\text{K kg mol}^{-1}.
\]

For a \(3\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\) NaCl solution, the density of water (\(1\;\text{g cm}^{-3}=1\;\text{kg L}^{-1}\)) gives a molality of  

\[
m = \frac{3\;\text{mol L}^{-1}}{1\;\text{kg L}^{-1}} = 3\;\text{mol kg}^{-1}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta T_{\mathrm f}= i K_{\mathrm f} m = 2 \times 1.86\;\text{K kg mol}^{-1}\times 3\;\text{mol kg}^{-1}
= 11.2\;\text{K}.
\]

The freezing point of the solution is therefore  

\[
T_{\text{freeze}} = T_{\text{melt}} - \Delta T_{\mathrm f}
= 273\;\text{K} - 11.2\;\text{K}
\approx 261.8\;\text{K}.
\]

\[
\boxed{261.8\ \text{K}}
\]

results.question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
results.llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has an initial composition  

\[
n_{\ce{CO}}^0 = 40\ \text{mol},\qquad 
n_{\ce{H2O}}^0 = 40\ \text{mol},\qquad 
n_{\ce{CO2}}^0 = 20\ \text{mol},\qquad 
n_{\ce{H2}}^0 = 20\ \text{mol}.
\]

Let \(x\) be the extent of the forward reaction. At equilibrium  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40 - x,\\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40 - x,\\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20 + x,\\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20 + x .
\end{aligned}
\]

The total number of moles remains constant:

\[
N = (40-x)+(40-x)+(20+x)+(20+x)=120\ \text{mol}.
\]

Because \(\Delta n_{\text{gas}} = 0\), the total pressure cancels in the expression for \(K_p\):

\[
K_p = \frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}
     = \frac{(n_{\ce{CO2}}/N)(n_{\ce{H2}}/N)}{(n_{\ce{CO}}/N)(n_{\ce{H2O}}/N)}
     = \frac{n_{\ce{CO2}}\,n_{\ce{H2}}}{n_{\ce{CO}}\,n_{\ce{H2O}}}.
\]

Insert the equilibrium amounts and the given \(K_p = 0.64\):

\[
0.64 = \frac{(20+x)(20+x)}{(40-x)(40-x)}.
\]

Taking the square root,

\[
\frac{20+x}{40-x}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8,
\]

\[
20 + x = 0.8(40 - x)=32 - 0.8x,
\]

\[
1.8x = 12 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x = \frac{12}{1.8}= \frac{20}{3}\ \text{mol}\approx 6.67\ \text{mol}.
\]

Hence the equilibrium amount of \(\ce{CO2}\) is  

\[
n_{\ce{CO2}} = 20 + x = 20 + \frac{20}{3}= \frac{80}{3}\ \text{mol}\approx 26.7\ \text{mol}.
\]

\[
\boxed{\frac{80}{3}\ \text{mol}}
\]

results.question: When fuel gases are supplied under the same pressure, the heat released per second in a burner is directly proportional to standard enthalpy change of combustion and inversely proportional to the square root of relative molecular mass. Assume hydrogen and methane are supplied under the same pressure. The heat released with \ce{H2} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and the heat released with \ce{CH4} is \pu{-890.3 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the ratio of heat released per second in a burner fuelled by hydrogen compared to in the same burner fuelled by methane?
results.llm_output:
The heat released per second \(P\) for a fuel is proportional to the magnitude of its standard enthalpy of combustion \(|\Delta H_{\text{comb}}|\) and inversely proportional to the square‑root of its relative molecular mass \(M\):

\[
P\propto\frac{|\Delta H_{\text{comb}}|}{\sqrt{M}} .
\]

Hence, for hydrogen and methane

\[
\frac{P_{\text{H}_2}}{P_{\text{CH}_4) }=
\frac{\displaystyle\frac{|\Delta H_{\text{H}_2}|}{\sqrt{M_{\text{H}_2}}}}
     {\displaystyle\frac{|\Delta H_{\text{CH}_4}|}{\sqrt{M_{\text{CH}_4}}}}
 =\frac{285.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}/\sqrt{2.016\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}}
        {890.3\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}/\sqrt{16.04\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}}.
\]

Evaluating the square‑roots:

\[
\sqrt{2.016}\approx1.420,\qquad 
\sqrt{16.04}\approx4.005,
\]

\[
\frac{285.8}{1.420}\approx201.2,\qquad 
\frac{890.3}{4.005}\approx222.3.
\]

Thus

\[
\frac{P_{\text{H}_2}}{P_{\text{CH}_4}}
=\frac{201.2}{222.3}\approx0.905.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.905}
\]

This question is about benzene and its isomers

Working out the structure of benzene, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{6}$, was one of the great achievements of $19^{\text {th }}$ century chemists. The carcinogenic hydrocarbon was first discovered by Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution in 1825 during the repeated fractional distillation of some oil residues.

Faraday analysed the pure benzene by passing its vapour over heated copper(II) oxide to produce carbon dioxide, water and copper. He collected and measured the volume of liquid water and gaseous $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced from a given mass of benzene.

Question: """This question is about benzene and its isomers

Working out the structure of benzene, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{6}$, was one of the great achievements of $19^{\text {th }}$ century chemists. The carcinogenic hydrocarbon was first discovered by Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution in 1825 during the repeated fractional distillation of some oil residues.

Faraday analysed the pure benzene by passing its vapour over heated copper(II) oxide to produce carbon dioxide, water and copper. He collected and measured the volume of liquid water and gaseous $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced from a given mass of benzene.

Calculate the maximum mass of water that could be formed from $0.644 \mathrm{mmol}$ of benzene using Faraday's method."""

Model's reasoning: """The combustion of benzene is  

\[
\mathrm{C_6H_6 + \frac{15}{2}\,O_2 \longrightarrow 6\,CO_2 + 3\,H_2O}
\]

Thus **1 mol of benzene produces 3 mol of water**.

---

### 1.  Moles of benzene  

\[
0.644\ \text{mmol}=0.644\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}=6.44\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

### 2.  Moles of water formed  

\[
n_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = 3 \times n_{\text{C}_6\text{H}_6}
                     = 3 \times 6.44\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
                     = 1.932\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

### 3.  Mass of water  

Molar mass of water: \(M_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = 18.015\ \text{g mol}^{-1}\)

\[
m_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = n_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} \times M_{\text{H}_2\text{O}}
                       = 1.932\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\times 18.015\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
                       = 3.4807\times10^{-2}\ \text{g}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{0.0348}\ \text{g}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 0.0348

Correct answer: 0.0348

Judgement:

results.question:
For sustainable energy, hydrogen appears to be the best energy carrier. The most efficient way of using hydrogen is generation of electrical energy in a fuel cell. However, storing hydrogen in large quantities is a challenge in fuel cell applications. Among the chemical hydrides considered as solid hydrogen storage materials, sodium borohydride $\left(\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}\right)$, being non-toxic, stable and environmentally benign, appears to be the most promising one. The hydrolysis of sodium borohydride that releases $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas is a slow reaction at ambient temperature and, therefore, needs to be catalyzed.

$$
\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(I)  \xrightarrow{catalyst} \mathrm{Na}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{BO}_{2}^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+4 \mathrm{H}_{2}(g)
$$

Colloidal ruthenium(0) nanoclusters are the most active catalysts in this hydrolysis even at room temperature and lead to a complete $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ release from sodium borohydride. Kinetic studies show that the catalytic hydrolysis of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ is a first order reaction with respect to the catalyst, but a zero order with respect to the substrate. The rate of hydrogen production per mole of ruthenium is $92 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_{2} \cdot(\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{Ru})^{-1} \cdot \min ^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.Calculate the amount of ruthenium catalyst (in $\mathrm{mg}$ ) which must be added to $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ solution with a concentration of $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ to supply the hydrogen gas at a rate of $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \cdot \mathrm{min}^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$, that is required for a portable fuel cell.

The hydrolysis of sodium borohydride that releases $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas is a slow reaction at ambient temperature and, therefore, needs to be catalyzed.

$$
\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(I)  \xrightarrow{catalyst} \mathrm{Na}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{BO}_{2}^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+4 \mathrm{H}_{2}(g)
$$

Colloidal ruthenium(0) nanoclusters are the most active catalysts in this hydrolysis even at room temperature and lead to a complete $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ release from sodium borohydride. Kinetic studies show that the catalytic hydrolysis of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ is a first order reaction with respect to the catalyst, but a zero order with respect to the substrate. The rate of hydrogen production per mole of ruthenium is $92 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_{2} \cdot(\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{Ru})^{-1} \cdot \min ^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.Calculate the amount of ruthenium catalyst (in $\mathrm{mg}$ ) which must be added to $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ solution with a concentration of $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ to supply the hydrogen gas at a rate of $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \cdot \mathrm{min}^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$, that is required for a portable fuel cell."""

Model's reasoning: """The required hydrogen‑generation rate is  

\[
\dot V_{\mathrm{H_2}} = 0.100\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{min}^{-1}=0.100\;\text{L min}^{-1}
\]

At \(25^{\circ}\text{C}=298\;\text{K}\) and \(P=1.0\;\text{atm}\) the ideal‑gas law gives the molar flow of \(\mathrm{H_2}\):

\[
\dot n_{\mathrm{H_2}}=\frac{PV}{RT}
      =\frac{(1.0\;\text{atm})(0.100\;\text{L})}
             {(0.082057\;\text{L atm mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\;\text{K})}
      =\frac{0.100}{24.452986}
      =4.09\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol min}^{-1}
\]

The catalyst produces \(92\;\text{mol H}_2\) per \(\text{mol Ru}\) per minute, therefore the molar amount of Ru needed is  

\[
\dot n_{\text{Ru}}=\frac{\dot n_{\mathrm{H_2}}}{92}
                 =\frac{4.09\times10^{-3}}{92}
                 =4.45\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol min}^{-1}
\]

Using the molar mass of ruthenium (\(M_{\text{Ru}} = 101.07\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\)):

\[
m_{\text{Ru}} = \dot n_{\text{Ru}}\,M_{\text{Ru}}
               = (4.45\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol})(101.07\;\text{g mol}^{-1})
               =4.49\times10^{-3}\;\text{g}
               =4.49\;\text{mg}
\]

\[
\boxed{4.49}\;\text{mg}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 4.49

Correct answer: 4.5

results.question:
Dissociating gas cycle

Dinitrogen tetroxide forms an equilibrium mixture with nitrogen dioxide:

$$
\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}(g) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NO}_{2}(g)
$$

1.00 mol of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ was put into an empty vessel with a fixed volume of $24.44 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$. The equilibrium gas pressure at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ was found to be 1.190 bar. When heated to $348 \mathrm{~K}$, the gas pressure increased to its equilibrium value of 1.886 bar.Calculate $\Delta S^{0}$ of the reaction, assuming that they do not change significantly with temperature.
results.llm_output:
The equilibrium constant at each temperature can be obtained from the measured total pressure.

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{tot}} &=\frac{PV}{RT},\qquad 
\xi = n_{\text{tot}}-1 \\[4pt]
y_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}} &=\frac{1-\xi}{n_{\text{tot}}},\qquad 
y_{\mathrm{NO_2}} =\frac{2\xi}{n_{\text{tot}}}\\[4pt]
p_i &=y_iP\\[4pt]
K_p &=\frac{p_{\mathrm{NO_2}}^{\,2}}{p_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}}
\end{aligned}
\]

| \(T\) (K) | \(P\) (bar) | \(\xi\) (mol) | \(K_p\) |
|-----------|-------------|---------------|----------|
| 298 | 1.190 | 0.1745 | 0.1496 |
| 348 | 1.886 | 0.594  | 4.111  |

Using the van’t Hoff relation  

\[
\ln K_p = -\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{RT}+\frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}{R}
\]

the slope of the line \(\ln K_p\) versus \(1/T\) gives  

\[
-\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}= \frac{\ln K_{2}-\ln K_{1}}{(1/T_{2})-(1/T_{1})}
      =-6.879\times10^{3}\;\text{K}
\]

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}=6.879\times10^{3}\;R = 5.72\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

The intercept yields  

\[
\frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}{R}= \ln K_{1}+ \frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}\frac{1}{T_{1}}
                         = 21.17
\]

\[
\Delta S^{\circ}=21.17\,R = 1.76\times10^{2}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
                = 0.176\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.176}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\]

results.question:
${ }^{131}$I is a radioactive isotope of iodine ( $\mathrm{e}^{-}$emitter) used in nuclear medicine for analytical procedures to determine thyroid endocrine disorders by scintigraphy. The decay rate constant, $k$, of ${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$ is $9.93 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$.

Knowing that a Geiger counter detects activities of the order of $10^{-4} \mu \mathrm{c}$, calculate the minimum amount of ${ }^{131}$ I (in grams) which could be detected by this counter.

1 Curie (c) is the amount of a radioisotope that produces $3.7 \times 10^{10}$ disintegrations $s^{1}$.
results.llm_output:
The Geiger counter can detect activities as low as  

\[
A_{\min}=10^{-4}\,\mu\text{c}=10^{-4}\times10^{-6}\,\text{c}=10^{-10}\,\text{c}.
\]

Since  

\[
1\;\text{c}=3.7\times10^{10}\;\text{disintegrations s}^{-1},
\]

the smallest detectable activity in becquerels is  

\[
A_{\min}=10^{-10}\times 3.7\times10^{10}\;\text{s}^{-1}=3.7\;\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

For a radioactive nuclide the activity is related to the number of atoms \(N\) by  

\[
A = kN,
\]

where the decay constant of \({}^{131}\text I\) is  

\[
k = 9.93\times10^{-7}\;\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

Hence the minimum number of atoms that can be detected is  

\[
N_{\min}= \frac{A_{\min}}{k}= \frac{3.7}{9.93\times10^{-7}}
          \approx 3.7\times10^{6}\;\text{atoms}.
\]

To convert this to mass, use the molar mass of \({}^{131}\text I\) (\(M = 131\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\)) and Avogadro’s number (\(N_A = 6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}\)):

\[
m_{\min}= N_{\min}\,\frac{M}{N_A}
        = 3.7\times10^{6}\times\frac{131\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}}
        \approx 8.1\times10^{-16}\;\text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.1\times10^{-16}}\ \text{g}
\]

Question: """${ }^{131}$I is a radioactive isotope of iodine ( $\mathrm{e}^{-}$emitter) used in nuclear medicine for analytical procedures to determine thyroid endocrine disorders by scintigraphy. The decay rate constant, $k$, of ${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$ is $9.93 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$.

Knowing that a Geiger counter detects activities of the order of $10^{-4} \mu \mathrm{c}$, calculate the minimum amount of ${ }^{131}$ I (in grams) which could be detected by this counter.

1 Curie (c) is the amount of a radioisotope that produces $3.7 \times 10^{10}$ disintegrations $s^{1}$."""

Model's reasoning: """The Geiger counter can detect activities as low as  

\[
A_{\min}=10^{-4}\,\mu\text{c}=10^{-4}\times10^{-6}\,\text{c}=10^{-10}\,\text{c}.
\]

Since  

\[
1\;\text{c}=3.7\times10^{10}\;\text{disintegrations s}^{-1},
\]

the smallest detectable activity in becquerels is  

\[
A_{\min}=10^{-10}\times 3.7\times10^{10}\;\text{s}^{-1}=3.7\;\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

For a radioactive nuclide the activity is related to the number of atoms \(N\) by  

\[
A = kN,
\]

where the decay constant of \({}^{131}\text I\) is  

\[
k = 9.93\times10^{-7}\;\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

Hence the minimum number of atoms that can be detected is  

\[
N_{\min}= \frac{A_{\min}}{k}= \frac{3.7}{9.93\times10^{-7}}
          \approx 3.7\times10^{6}\;\text{atoms}.
\]

To convert this to mass, use the molar mass of \({}^{131}\text I\) (\(M = 131\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\)) and Avogadro’s number (\(N_A = 6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}\)):

\[
m_{\min}= N_{\min}\,\frac{M}{N_A}
        = 3.7\times10^{6}\times\frac{131\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{6.022\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}}
        \approx 8.1\times10^{-16}\;\text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.1\times10^{-16}}\ \text{g}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 8.100000E-16

Correct answer: 8.110000E-16

results.question:
Extraction of gold using sodium cyanide, a very poisonous chemical, causes environmental problems and gives rise to serious public concern about the use of this so called "cyanide process". Thiosulfate leaching of gold has been considered as an alternative. In this process, the main reagent is ammonium thiosulfate, $\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, which is relatively non-toxic. Although this process appears to be environmentally benign, the chemistry involved is very complex and needs to be studied thoroughly. The solution used for leaching gold contains $\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}, \mathrm{NH}_{3}$, and dissolved $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. The solution must have a $\mathrm{pH}$ greater than 8.5 to allow free ammonia to be present.

According to the proposed mechanism, a local voltaic micro-cell is formed on the surface of gold particles during the leaching process and operates as follows:

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex.
results.llm_output:
The gold present in solution can exist as free Au⁺, the ammine complex \([\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{NH}_3)_2]^+\) and the thiosulfate complex \([\mathrm{Au}(S_2O_3)_2]^{3-}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
K_{f1}&=\frac{[\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{NH}_3)_2^+]}{[\mathrm{Au}^+][\mathrm{NH}_3]^2}=1.0\times10^{26}\\[4pt]
K_{f2}&=\frac{[\mathrm{Au}(S_2O_3)_2^{3-}]}{[\mathrm{Au}^+][S_2O_3^{2-}]^2}=1.0\times10^{28}
\end{aligned}
\]

With \([\mathrm{NH}_3]=0.100\ \text{M}\) and \([S_2O_3^{2-}]=0.100\ \text{M}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{NH}_3)_2^+] &= K_{f1}[\mathrm{Au}^+](0.100)^2 = 1.0\times10^{24}[\mathrm{Au}^+]\\
[\mathrm{Au}(S_2O_3)_2^{3-}] &= K_{f2}[\mathrm{Au}^+](0.100)^2 = 1.0\times10^{26}[\mathrm{Au}^+]
\end{aligned}
\]

The mass balance for gold is

\[
[\mathrm{Au}]_{\text{tot}} = [\mathrm{Au}^+] + 1.0\times10^{24}[\mathrm{Au}^+] + 1.0\times10^{26}[\mathrm{Au}^+]
      = \bigl(1 + 1.0\times10^{24} + 1.0\times10^{26}\bigr)[\mathrm{Au}^+].
\]

Hence

\[
[\mathrm{Au}^+] = \frac{[\mathrm{Au}]_{\text{tot}}}{1 + 1.0\times10^{24} + 1.0\times10^{26}}
                \approx \frac{5.50\times10^{-5}}{1.01\times10^{26}}
                = 5.45\times10^{-31}\ \text{M}.
\]

The concentration of the thiosulfate complex is then

\[
[\mathrm{Au}(S_2O_3)_2^{3-}] = 1.0\times10^{26}\,[\mathrm{Au}^+] 
                              = 1.0\times10^{26}\times5.45\times10^{-31}
                              = 5.45\times10^{-5}\ \text{M}.
\]

The fraction of gold present as this complex is

\[
\frac{[\mathrm{Au}(S_2O_3)_2^{3-}]}{[\mathrm{Au}]_{\text{tot}}}
   = \frac{5.45\times10^{-5}}{5.50\times10^{-5}}
   = \frac{1.0\times10^{26}}{1.01\times10^{26}}
   = 0.9901.
\]

Thus the percentage of gold(I) existing as the thiosulfate complex is

\[
0.9901 \times 100\% = 99.0\%.
\]

\[
\boxed{99.0}\ \%
\]

results.question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

Estimate the temperature at which the reaction would have an equilibrium constant equal to 1. Ignore slight variations in the thermodynamic data with temperature.
results.llm_output:
The equilibrium constant \(K\) is related to the standard Gibbs energy change by  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= -RT\ln K .
\]

For \(K=1\) we have \(\Delta G^{\circ}=0\), so the temperature at which the reaction is at equilibrium satisfies  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= \Delta H^{\circ}-T\Delta S^{\circ}=0\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
T=\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{\Delta S^{\circ}} .
\]

For the phase transition \(\mathrm{CO_2(g)}\rightleftharpoons\mathrm{CO_2(s)}\) (sublimation) the standard enthalpy and entropy changes are, to a good approximation, temperature‑independent:

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}_{\text{sub}} \approx 2.52\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1},
\qquad
\Delta S^{\circ}_{\text{sub}} \approx 1.30\times10^{2}\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

Hence  

\[
T = \frac{2.52\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}}{1.30\times10^{2}\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}}
   \approx 1.94\times10^{2}\ \text{K}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.94\times10^{2}}\ \text{K}
\]

The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in the completely charged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially.

Question: """The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in the completely charged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially."""

Model's reasoning: """The overall reaction for charging (the reverse of discharge) is  

\[
\mathrm{LiCoO_2}+6\,\mathrm{C}\;\longrightarrow\;\mathrm{LiC_6}+\mathrm{CoO_2}
\]

---

### 1.  Molar masses  

\[
\begin{aligned}
M(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}) &= 6.94+58.93+2(16.00)=97.87\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\\[2pt]
M(\mathrm{C}) &= 12.01\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\\[2pt]
M(\mathrm{LiC_6}) &= 6.94+6(12.01)=79.00\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2.  Initial moles  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}} &= \frac{10.00\;\text{g}}{97.87\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.1022\;\text{mol}\\[4pt]
n_{\mathrm{C}} &= \frac{10.00\;\text{g}}{12.01\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.8326\;\text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 3.  Limiting reagent  

The reaction needs \(6\) mol C per mol LiCoO₂:

\[
n_{\mathrm{C,\,required}} = 6 \times 0.1022 = 0.6132\;\text{mol}
\]

Since \(0.8326\;\text{mol} > 0.6132\;\text{mol}\), carbon is in excess and LiCoO₂ is the limiting reagent.

---

### 4.  Amount of product formed  

\[
n_{\mathrm{LiC_6}} = n_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}} = 0.1022\;\text{mol}
\]

Mass of LiC₆:

\[
m_{\mathrm{LiC_6}} = n_{\mathrm{LiC_6}}\,M(\mathrm{LiC_6})
                 = 0.1022\;\text{mol}\times 79.00\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
                 = 8.074\;\text{g}
\]

Remaining carbon:

\[
n_{\mathrm{C,\,remaining}} = 0.8326 - 0.6132 = 0.2194\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
m_{\mathrm{C,\,remaining}} = 0.2194\;\text{mol}\times 12.01\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
                         = 2.635\;\text{g}
\]

---

### 5.  Total mass of the anode in the fully‑charged state  

\[
m_{\text{anode}} = m_{\mathrm{LiC_6}} + m_{\mathrm{C,\,remaining}}
                 = 8.074\;\text{g} + 2.635\;\text{g}
                 = 10.71\;\text{g}
\]

\[
\boxed{10.71}\ \text{g}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 10.71

Correct answer: 10.71

Judgement:

Model's reasoning: """The overall discharge reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{LiC_6}+ \mathrm{CoO_2}\;\longrightarrow\;6\,\mathrm{C}+ \mathrm{LiCoO_2}
\]

\[
M(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}) = 6.94\;(\text{Li}) + 58.93\;(\text{Co}) + 2\times16.00\;(\text{O}) = 97.87\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
n_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}} = \frac{10.00\;\text{g}}{97.87\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.1022\;\text{mol}
\]

Each mole of \(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}\) corresponds to 6 mol of C atoms:

\[
m_{\text{extra C}} = 6\,n_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}} \times M(\mathrm{C})
               = 6(0.1022\;\text{mol})\times 12.01\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
               = 7.357\;\text{g}
\]

\[
m_{\text{anode, final}} = m_{\text{initial C}} + m_{\text{extra C}}
                         = 10.00\;\text{g} + 7.357\;\text{g}
                         = 17.36\;\text{g}

results.question:
Lactic acid is formed in the muscles during intense activity (anaerobic metabolism). In the blood, lactic acid is neutralized by reaction with hydrogen carbonate. This will be illustrated by the following calculations:

Lactic acid written as HL is monoprotic, and the acid dissociation constant is $K_{\mathrm{HL}}=1.4 \times 10^{-4}$.

The acid dissociation constants for carbonic acid are: $K_{\mathrm{a} 1}=4.5 \times 10^{-7}$ and $K_{\mathrm{a} 2}=$ $4.7 \times 10^{-11}$. All carbon dioxide remains dissolved during the reactions.

$\mathrm{pH}$ in the blood of a person changed from 7.40 to 7.00 due to lactic acid formed during physical activity. Let an aqueous solution having $\mathrm{pH}=7.40$ and $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]=$ 0.022 represent blood in the following calculation. How many moles of lactic acid have been added to $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of this solution when its $\mathrm{pH}$ has become 7.00 ?
results.llm_output:
The decrease in bicarbonate concentration caused by the added acid is obtained from the carbonate‑buffer equilibrium.

**Initial solution (pH = 7.40)**  

\[
[H^+]_i =10^{-7.40}=3.98\times10^{-8}\ \text{M}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
[H_2CO_3]_i &=\frac{[H^+]_i[HCO_3^-]_i}{K_{a1}}
            =\frac{(3.98\times10^{-8})(0.022)}{4.5\times10^{-7}}
            =1.95\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}\\[4pt]
[CO_3^{2-}]_i &=\frac{K_{a2}[HCO_3^-]_i}{[H^+]_i}
               =\frac{(4.7\times10^{-11})(0.022)}{3.98\times10^{-8}}
               =2.6\times10^{-5}\ \text{M}
\end{aligned}
\]

Total dissolved carbonic species  

\[
C_T=[H_2CO_3]_i+[HCO_3^-]_i+[CO_3^{2-}]_i
    =0.022+1.95\times10^{-3}+2.6\times10^{-5}
    =2.398\times10^{-2}\ \text{M}
\]

**Final solution (pH = 7.00)**  

\[
[H^+]_f =10^{-7}=1.00\times10^{-7}\ \text{M}
\]

Let \([HCO_3^-]_f = x\).  At the new pH

\[
[H_2CO_3]_f =\frac{[H^+]_f x}{K_{a1}}=\frac{x}{4.5},\qquad
[CO_3^{2-}]_f =\frac{K_{a2}x}{[H^+]_f}=4.7\times10^{-4}x
\]

Hence  

\[
C_T = x+\frac{x}{4.5}+4.7\times10^{-4}x
     =x\bigl(1+0.2222+0.00047\bigr)=1.2227\,x
\]

\[
x =\frac{C_T}{1.2227}= \frac{2.398\times10^{-2}}{1.2227}
   =1.962\times10^{-2}\ \text{M}
\]

Thus  

\[
\Delta[HCO_3^-]=0.0220-0.01962=2.38\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}
\]

Each mole of \(\mathrm{HCO_3^-}\) that disappears consumes one mole of \(\mathrm{H^+}\); therefore the amount of \(\mathrm{H^+}\) generated by the added lactic acid is essentially \(2.38\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}\).

**Lactic‑acid equilibrium**

\[
\mathrm{HL}\rightleftharpoons\mathrm{H^+}+\mathrm{L^-},\qquad
K_{HL}=1.4\times10^{-4}
\]

At pH = 7.00, \([H^+]=1.0\times10^{-7}\) M, so  

\[
\frac{[L^-]}{[HL]}=\frac{K_{HL}}{[H^+]}=
\frac{1.4\times10^{-4}}{1.0\times10^{-7}}=1400
\]

Hence \([L^-]=1400[HL]\) and the total lactic‑acid concentration is  

\[
C_{\text{LA}}=[HL]+[L^-]=[HL](1+1400)=1401[HL]
\]

Since \([L^-]\) equals the amount of \(\mathrm{H^+}\) produced,

\[
[L^-]=2.38\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}\;\Longrightarrow\;
C_{\text{LA}}=\frac{1401}{1400}\,[L^-]
            =1.0007\times2.38\times10^{-3}
            =2.38\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}
\]

For a volume of \(1.00\ \text{dm}^3\) (1 L) the moles of lactic acid added are

\[
n_{\text{LA}} = C_{\text{LA}}\times V = 2.38\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.38\times10^{-3}}\ \text{mol}
\]

results.question:
In quantum mechanics, the movement of $\pi$ electrons along a neutral chain of conjugated carbon atoms may be modeled using the 'particle in a box' method. The energy of the $\pi$ electrons is given by the following equation:

$$
E_{\mathrm{n}}=\frac{n^{2} h^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}
$$

where $n$ is the quantum number $(n=1,2,3, \ldots), h$ is Planck's constant, $m$ is the mass of electron, and $L$ is the length of the box which may be approximated by $L=(k+2) \times 1.40 \AA$ ( $k$ being the number of conjugated double bonds along the carbon chain in the molecule). A photon with the appropriate wavelength $\lambda$ may promote $a$ m electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). An approximate semi-empirical formula based on this model which relates the wavelength $\lambda$, to the number of double bonds $k$ and constant $B$ is as follows:

$$
\lambda(\mathrm{nm})=B \times \frac{(k+2)^{2}}{(2 k+1)}
$$Using this semi-empirical formula with $B=65.01 \mathrm{~nm}$ calculate the value of the wavelength $\lambda(\mathrm{nm})$ for octatetraene $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{2}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}_{2}\right)$.

results.question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

From the data given in the phase diagram, calculate the molar enthalpy change of sublimation of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$. Write down the formula used.
results.llm_output:
The isothermal expansion of the CO₂ sample is carried out at a constant external pressure \(P_{\text{ext}}=1.00\;\text{bar}\).  
For an isothermal, reversible (or quasi‑reversible) expansion of an ideal gas the change in internal energy is zero \((\Delta U=0)\); therefore the heat exchanged with the surroundings equals the work done on the system:

\[
\Delta U = q + w = 0 \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\; q = -w .
\]

The mechanical work performed by the gas against the constant external pressure is

\[
w = -P_{\text{ext}}\Delta V = -P_{\text{ext}}\,(V_{\text{final}}-V_{\text{initial}}).
\]

Hence the molar enthalpy change for the sublimation (which, under the given conditions, is equal to the heat absorbed per mole) is

\[
\boxed{\Delta H_{\text{sub}} = \frac{-w}{n}
      = \frac{P_{\text{ext}}\,(V_{\text{final}}-V_{\text{initial}})}{n}} .
\]

Substituting the numerical data (remember that \(1\;\text{bar·dm}^{3}=100\;\text{J}\)):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_{\text{sub}}
&= \frac{(1.00\;\text{bar})\,(30.0\;\text{dm}^{3}-10.0\;\text{dm}^{3})}{3.00\;\text{mol}} \\[4pt]
&= \frac{20.0\;\text{bar·dm}^{3}}{3.00\;\text{mol}}
   = \frac{20.0 \times 100\;\text{J}}{3.00\;\text{mol}} \\[4pt]
&= \frac{2000\;\text{J}}{3.00\;\text{mol}}
   = 6.67\times10^{2}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
   = 0.667\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.667}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

results.question:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HA in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$
results.llm_output:
The solution contains the two weak acids  

\[
\mathrm{HA}\;(K_{a}=1.74\times10^{-7}),\qquad 
\mathrm{HB}\;(K_{a}=1.34\times10^{-7})
\]

with initial concentrations \(C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{HB}}^{0}\) (mol dm\(^{-3}\)).  

---

### 1.  Information from the titration  

The amount of NaOH required to neutralise the whole sample equals the total amount of acidic protons initially present:

\[
n_{\mathrm{NaOH}} = V_{\mathrm{NaOH}}c_{\mathrm{NaOH}}
                 = 0.\;\text{dm}^{3}\times0.220\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
                 = 0.0220\;\text{mol}
\]

Since each acid molecule can donate one proton,

\[
(C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}+C_{\mathrm{HB}}^{0})V_{\text{sample}} = 0.0220\;\text{mol}
\]

with \(V_{\text{sample}}=0.100\;\text{dm}^{3}\). Hence  

\[
\boxed{C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}+C_{\mathrm{HB}}^{0}=0.22\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}} \tag{1}
\]

---

### 2.  Information from the pH  

\[
[\mathrm{H}^{+}] = 10^{-\text{pH}} = 10^{-3.75}=1.78\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

Let \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(x_{\mathrm{B}}\) be the amounts of HA and HB that dissociate:

\[
x_{\mathrm{A}}+x_{\mathrm{B}} = [\mathrm{H}^{+}] \tag{2}
\]

For each weak acid  

\[
K_{a}= \frac{x[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}{C^{0}-x}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
x = \frac{K_{a}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]+K_{a}}\,C^{0}
\]

Define  

\[
\alpha_{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{K_{a,\mathrm{A}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
      =\frac{1.74\times10^{-7}}{1.78\times10^{-4}}=9.78\times10^{-4},
\]
\[
\alpha_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{K_{a,\mathrm{B}}}{[\mathrm{H}^{+}]}
      =\frac{1.34\times10^{-7}}{1.78\times10^{-4}}=7.53\times10^{-4}.
\]

Because \(\alpha\ll 1\),

\[
x_{\mathrm{A}}\simeq\alpha_{\mathrm{A}}C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0},\qquad
x_{\mathrm{B}}\simeq\alpha_{\mathrm{B}}C_{\mathrm{HB}}^{0}.
\]

Insert these into (2):

\[
\alpha_{\mathrm{A}}C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}+\alpha_{\mathrm{B}}C_{\mathrm{HB}}^{0}=1.78\times10^{-4}. \tag{3}
\]

---

### 3.  Solve for \(C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}\)

Using (1) to eliminate \(C_{\mathrm{HB}}^{0}=0.22-C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}\) in (3):

\[
\alpha_{\mathrm{A}}C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}
+\alpha_{\mathrm{B}}(0.22-C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0})=1.78\times10^{-4},
\]

\[
(\alpha_{\mathrm{A}}-\alpha_{\mathrm{B}})C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}
+0.22\,\alpha_{\mathrm{B}} = 1.78\times10^{-4}.
\]

Insert the numerical values:

\[
(9.78\times10^{-4}-7.53\times10^{-4})C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}
+0.22(7.53\times10^{-4}) = 1.78\times10^{-4},
\]

\[
2.25\times10^{-4}\,C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}+1.66\times10^{-4}=1.78\times10^{-4},
\]

\[
2.25\times10^{-4}\,C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}=1.21\times10^{-5},
\]

\[
C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}=5.4\times10^{-2}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{5.4\times10^{-2}}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]

\]

\[

\[

\]

+\alpha_{\mathrm{B}}(0.22-C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0})=1.78\times10^{-4},
\]

\[
(\alpha_{\mathrm{A}}-\alpha_{\mathrm{B}})C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}
+0.22\,\alpha_{\mathrm{B}} = 1.78\times10^{-4}.
\]

Insert the numerical values:

\[
(9.78\times10^{-4}-7.53\times10^{-4})C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}
+0.22(7.53\times10^{-4}) = 1.78\times10^{-4},
\]

\[
2.25\times10^{-4}\,C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}+1.66\times10^{-4}=1.78\times10^{-4},
\]

\[
2.25\times10^{-4}\,C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}=1.21\times10^{-5},
\]

\[
C_{\mathrm{HA}}^{0}=5.4\times10^{-2}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{5.4\times10^{-2}}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]"""

results.question:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HB in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$
results.llm_output:
The titration consumes one mole of \(\mathrm{OH^-}\) for each acidic proton initially present.  

\[
\begin{aligned}
V_{\text{X}} &= 100\;\text{cm}^{3}=0.100\;\text{L}\\
V_{\text{NaOH}} &= 100\;\text{cm}^{3}=0.100\;\text{L}\\
c_{\text{NaOH}} &=0.220\;\text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\end{aligned}
\]

Moles of \(\mathrm{OH^-}\) added  

\[
n_{\mathrm{OH^-}} = V_{\text{NaOH}}c_{\text{NaOH}}
                 =0.100\;\text{L}\times0.220\;\text{mol·L}^{-1}
                 =0.0220\;\text{mol}
\]

Hence the total initial concentration of acidic protons in the 0.100 L sample is  

\[
c_{\text{HA}}+c_{\text{HB}}=\frac{0.0220\;\text{mol}}{0.100\;\text{L}}=0.220\;\text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\tag{1}
\]

---

### Using the measured pH

\[
\text{pH}=3.75\;\Longrightarrow\;[H^+]=10^{-3.75}=1.78\times10^{-4}\;\text{M}
\]

For each weak acid \(HA\) and \(HB\)

\[
K_{a1}=1.74\times10^{-7}=\frac{[H^+][A^-]}{[HA]},\qquad
K_{a2}=1.34\times10^{-7}=\frac{[H^+][B^-]}{[HB]}
\]

Because \(K_a/[H^+] \ll 1\) (≈\(10^{-3}\)), we may use the approximation  

\[
[A^-]\simeq c_{\text{HA}}\frac{K_{a1}}{[H^+]},\qquad
[B^-]\simeq c_{\text{HB}}\frac{K_{a2}}{[H^+]}
\]

Charge balance at the given pH gives  

\[
[H^+] \simeq [A^-]+[B^-]
\]

\[
[H^+] \simeq c_{\text{HA}}\frac{K_{a1}}{[H^+]}+c_{\text{HB}}\frac{K_{a2}}{[H^+]}
\]

Multiplying by \([H^+]\) :

\[
[H^+]^{2}=c_{\text{HA}}K_{a1}+c_{\text{HB}}K_{a2}
\tag{2}
\]

Insert the numerical values  

\[
(1.78\times10^{-4})^{2}=c_{\text{HA}}(1.74\times10^{-7})+c_{\text{HB}}(1.34\times10^{-7})
\]

\[
3.16\times10^{-8}=1.74\times10^{-7}c_{\text{HA}}+1.34\times10^{-7}c_{\text{HB}}
\tag{3}
\]

---

### Solving (1) and (3)

From (1): \(c_{\text{HB}}=0.220-c_{\text{HA}}\).

Substituting into (3):

\[
1.74\times10^{-7}c_{\text{HA}}+1.34\times10^{-7}(0.220-c_{\text{HA}})=3.16\times10^{-8}
\]

\[
(1.74-1.34)\times10^{-7}c_{\text{HA}}+1.34\times10^{-7}\times0.220=3.16\times10^{-8}
\]

\[
4.0\times10^{-8}c_{\text{HA}}+2.95\times10^{-8}=3.16\times10^{-8}
\]

\[
c_{\text{HA}}=\frac{3.16\times10^{-8}-2.95\times10^{-8}}{4.0\times10^{-8}}
            =0.0555\;\text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]

Finally  

\[
c_{\text{HB}}=0.220-0.0555=0.1645\;\text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{0.165}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]
